title: On symmetric hollow integer matrices with eigenvalues bounded from below
abstract:
A hollow matrix is a square matrix whose diagonal entries are all equal to
zero. Define $\lambda^* = \rho^{1/2} + \rho^{-1/2} \approx 2.01980$, where
$\rho$ is the unique real root of $x^3 = x + 1$. We show that for every
$\lambda < \lambda^*$, there exists $n \in \mathbb{N}$ such that if a symmetric
hollow integer matrix has an eigenvalue less than $-\lambda$, then one of its
principal submatrices of order at most $n$ does as well. However, the same
conclusion does not hold for any $\lambda \ge \lambda^*$.
